K.Text: Handling of Thermal Receipts as a Source of Exposure to Bisphenol A

Content.Text: Handling of Thermal Receipts as a Source of Exposure to
Bisphenol A

K.Text: 1  and neurodevelopment in children exposed perinatally. 2  Exposure to BPA is primarily through dietary ingestion, including consumption of canned foods. 3  A less-studied source of exposure is thermal receipt paper, 4  handled daily by many people at supermarkets, ATM machines, gas stations, and other settings. We hypothesized that handling of thermal receipts significantly increases BPA exposure, but use of gloves during handling minimizes exposure.

Content.Text: and neurodevelopment in children exposed
perinatally.
Exposure to BPA is primarily through dietary ingestion, including consumption
of canned foods.
A less-studied source of exposure is thermal receipt paper,
handled daily
by many people at supermarkets, ATM machines, gas stations, and other settings. We
hypothesized that handling of thermal receipts significantly increases BPA exposure, but use
of gloves during handling minimizes exposure.

K.Text: Author Contributions: Dr Ehrlich had full access to all of the data in the study and takes responsibility for the integrity of the data and the accuracy of the data analysis.

Content.Text: Author Contributions:
Dr Ehrlich had full access to all of the data in the study and takes responsibility for the integrity of the data
and the accuracy of the data analysis.

K.Text: All participants provided a spot urine sample, collected in a sterile BPA-free polypropylene specimen cup, immediately before handling of receipts and 4 hours later. Volunteers provided additional sequential urine samples at 8, 12, and 24 hours after handling of receipts without gloves. Urinary-specific gravity was measured using a handheld refractometer. Urine was stored in polypropylene cryogenic vials at or below −20°C until analysis. Total (free plus conjugated species) urinary BPA concentration was measured at the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention using published methods. 1

Content.Text: All participants provided a spot urine sample, collected in a sterile BPA-free polypropylene
specimen cup, immediately before handling of receipts and 4 hours later. Volunteers
provided additional sequential urine samples at 8, 12, and 24 hours after handling of receipts
without gloves. Urinary-specific gravity was measured using a handheld refractometer.
Urine was stored in polypropylene cryogenic vials at or below −20°C until analysis. Total
(free plus conjugated species) urinary BPA concentration was measured at the US Centers
for Disease Control and Prevention using published methods.

Content.Text: The clinical implications of the height of the peak level and the

K.Text: In this pilot study, we observed an increase in urinary BPA concentrations after continuously handling receipts for 2 hours without gloves, but no significant increase when using gloves. The peak level (5.8 µg/L) was lower than that observed after canned soup consumption (20.8µg/L).

Content.Text: In this pilot study, we observed an increase in urinary BPA concentrations after
continuously handling receipts for 2 hours without gloves, but no significant increase when
using gloves. The peak level (5.8 µg/L) was lower than that observed after canned soup
consumption (20.8µg/L).

K.Text: Concentrations of BPA were adjusted for specific gravity to account for urine dilution.

Content.Text: Concentrations of BPA were
adjusted for specific gravity to account for urine dilution.

K.Text: Using SAS version 9.3 (SAS Institute Inc), mixed regression models were used to examine associations between log-transformed specific gravity–adjusted urinary BPA concentrations for prehandling and posthandling samples and across time points for those who provided sequential urine samples. Statistical significance was set at a P ≤ .05 (2-sided test).

Content.Text: Using SAS version 9.3 (SAS Institute Inc), mixed regression models were used to examine
associations between log-transformed specific gravity–adjusted urinary BPA concentrations
for prehandling and posthandling samples and across time points for those who provided
sequential urine samples. Statistical significance was set at a
P
≤ .05 (2-sided test).

K.Text: receipts wearing nitrile gloves. The option to participate in the second simulation or to provide sequential urine samples following the first simulation was offered to all participants at study entry.

Content.Text: receipts wearing nitrile gloves. The option to participate in the second simulation or to
provide sequential urine samples following the first simulation was offered to all
participants at study entry.
Results

K.Text: Twenty-four volunteers (mean age [SD], 35 [12] years) provided at least 2 urine samples for the simulation without gloves; 12 volunteers provided additional sequential samples and 12 also completed the simulation with gloves (Table). We excluded 1 participant for reporting consumption of 4 cans of beverage prior to the simulation (baseline urinary BPA concentration of 49.3 µg/L vs <2 µg/L for the remaining participants, decreasing to 12.0 µg/L postsimulation).

Content.Text: Twenty-four volunteers (mean age [SD], 35 [12] years) provided at least 2 urine samples for
the simulation without gloves; 12 volunteers provided additional sequential samples and 12
also completed the simulation with gloves (Table). We excluded 1 participant for reporting
consumption of 4 cans of beverage prior to the simulation (baseline urinary BPA
concentration of 49.3 µg/L vs <2 µg/L for the remaining participants, decreasing to 12.0
µg/L postsimulation).

K.Text: We detected BPA in 83% (n = 20) of samples at baseline and in 100% of samples after handling receipts without gloves. The geometric mean urinary BPA concentration was 1.8 µg/L (95% CI, 1.3–2.4 µg/L) before simulation and 5.8 µg/L (95% CI, 4.0–8.4 µg/L) postsimulation (P = .005 for interaction between presimulation and postsimulation BPA and glove status). The geometric mean BPA urinary concentrations from 12 participants who provided sequential samples following receipt handling without gloves were 2.1 µg/L (95% CI, 1.4–3.3 µg/L) at baseline, 6.0 µg/L (95% CI, 3.4–10.7 µg/L) at 4 hours, 11.1 µg/L (95% CI, 5.5–22.8 µg/L) at 8 hours, 10.5 µg/L (95%CI, 4.9–22.6 µg/L) at 12 hours, and 4.7 µg/L (95%CI, 2.4–9.1 µg/L) at 24 hours. Each measure was significantly different from baseline (P < .001 for 4-hour, 8-hour, and 12-hour urine samples and P = .04 for 24-hour samples). We observed no significant increase in urinary BPA after handling receipts with gloves (Figure).

handling receipts without gloves. The geometric mean urinary BPA concentration was 1.8
µg/L (95% CI, 1.3–2.4 µg/L) before simulation and 5.8 µg/L (95% CI, 4.0–8.4 µg/L)

(95%CI, 2.4–9.1 µg/L) at 24 hours. Each measure was significantly different from baseline
P
< .001 for 4-hour, 8-hour, and 12-hour urine samples and
P
= .04 for 24-hour samples).
We observed no significant increase in urinary BPA after handling receipts with gloves
(Figure).
Discussion

K.Text: 5  who handle receipts 40 or more hours per week.

Content.Text: who handle receipts 40 or more hours per week.

K.Text: Limitations include the small volunteer sample and loss of participants in the second simulation. However, urinary BPA concentrations at baseline were similar in the full and smaller groups and similar to the US population (1.83 µg/L). 6  A larger study is needed to confirm our findings and evaluate the clinical implications.

Content.Text: Limitations include the small volunteer sample and loss of participants in the second
simulation. However, urinary BPA concentrations at baseline were similar in the full and
smaller groups and similar to the US population (1.83 µg/L).
A larger study is needed to
confirm our findings and evaluate the clinical implications.
